results.justification: The document explicitly states the research aims to investigate the validity and generalisability of trace-SRL. (Section 3)
Section 4 provides a detailed overview of the study process, broken down into sections 4.1-4.4, outlining the study context, data collection, pre-processing, and data analysis steps.
The document does not mention the public availability of the raw or processed datasets.
While privacy concerns aren't explicitly stated, there's no mention of data sharing, suggesting it's not available.

Table 1 and sections 4.3.1-4.3.3 provide details on the data collected, including the SRL questionnaire, daily SRL survey, and trace data, along with descriptions of variables and preprocessing steps.
Data collection methods are fully described in section 4.3, detailing the surveys and trace data collection process.
The document does not mention the availability of the analysis code in a public repository.
No justification is provided for the lack of code sharing.
The document mentions data preprocessing but does not state whether the code used for this purpose is shared.
Statistical tests (Wilcoxon signed-rank test, Pearson correlation), models (mixed linear models), and assumptions are described in section 4.4.1.
P-values are reported throughout section 5.1, and ICC values are calculated and reported.
The analysis is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
No qualitative data coding or analysis is described.
Results are clearly presented in sections 5.1, 5.2, and 5.3, with tables and figures summarizing the findings.
Limitations related to data imbalance and self-report measures are discussed in section 6.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration.
